statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Jared Dudley scored 21 points, Craig Smith added 20 and Boston College (No. 17 ESPN/USA Today, No. 13 AP) beat slumping West Virginia (No. 24 ESPN/USA Today) 73-53 Sunday.
article.headline: Soaring Eagles win eighth straight on road
article.linkText: Unbeaten BC routs Mountaineers for 14th win
article.story: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. (AP) -- Boston College remained one of four unbeaten teams in Division I-A -- and now wants to join the other three in the Top 10. Jared Dudley scored 21 points, Craig Smith had 20 and the Eagles (No. 17 ESPN/USA Today, No. 13 AP) beat slumping West Virginia 73-53 on Sunday for the Eagles' eighth straight road win. The Eagles, No. 1 Illinois, Kansas (No. 2 ESPN/USA Today, No. 3 AP) and No. 5 Duke are the only undefeated teams in Division I. "I would say top 10," Dudley said when asked where BC should be ranked. "I would not say top FIVE. All those top five teams are proven year in and year out. I do think we are an elite team that has won some big home and road games. We are on the radar now." Boston College (14-0, 3-0 Big East) extended the best start in school history and won its first three conference games for the first time under eighth-year coach Al Skinner. BC's 14-game winning streak is the school's longest since a 19-game run during the 1968-69 season. "We have the total package," Smith said. "Anybody on this team is deadly enough to score 20 points any night, and the way we play defense is tremendous." Mike Gansey scored 14 points and Tyrone Sally had 13 for West Virginia (11-3, 1-2), which has lost three of four games after starting the season 10-0. In each loss, the Mountaineers were held below 21 percent from beyond the 3-point line. They were just 3-for-23 on 3-point attempts Sunday. "It was almost impossible to get the ball inside," West Virginia coach John Beilein said. "There were times we should have penetrated, but we were forced to take those outside shots. We're going to have to make some to win." With West Virginia struggling from the outside, BC packed its defense in the middle. Center D'or Fischer, West Virginia's second-leading scorer, was held to five points and took just three attempts. "I thought our interior defense was very good," Skinner said. "We forced them outside and had several people to throw at Fischer." Dudley scored the final four points of a 12-4 run that tied the game at halftime and then scored six more as the Eagles opened the second half with a 18-2 spurt that gave them a 47-31 lead. The Mountaineers never recovered. Boston College showed few signs of rust despite having a week off after beating then-No. 10 Connecticut on the road and Providence at home. Dudley caught the crowd's ire after he sarcastically gestured for them to make more noise following a dunk during the second-half run. He was called for a technical foul late in the game when he put his finger to his lips as if to quiet the crowd after another dunk. After West Virginia closed within 63-50, BC went on a 9-2 run to seal the Mountaineers' first home loss of the season. Boston College shot 63 percent from the floor in the second half. "Unlike other teams, we are not a 3-point shooting team, so we are not going to shoot ourselves out of it," Dudley said. "We run our flexible half-court offense and get key stops in situations and don't take bad shots." Boston College is 21-13 in Big East road games since 2000, tops in the league. Only Notre Dame also has a winning road record in the league since then.
